In the morning the hotel keeper found the robber! Jack was sentenced to be hanged from the shaft of a sidecar. He asked one request before being hanged - leave to put on his red cap.The hangman got on the car. "High over to Ireland," said Jack. At once Jack, car and hangman were all flying to Ireland. As they were passing over the English Channel Jack gave a cuff to the hangman. He himself landed home safe and sound to his mother in Connemara, but the hangman went to the bottom of the sea.

Willie the wispOnce upon a time there lived a blacksmith who was very tall, and on that account he was called "Willie the wisp." This blacksmith was very fond of drink and one day as he was going towards his forge, the devil came to him with a purse. He said "I will give you this purse which is never empty if you promise to come with me after seven years." "Well if I get the purse, I will go with you after seven years" said Willie.On getting the purse he was delighted. but he never told anybody, lest it might be stolen. About a year afterwards, one morning on going to his forge, he saw a little man standing outside, who seemed to be shivering with the cold. He told him to come in and warm him self, this the stranger did, but on leaving he told Willie he would grant him any wish he desired. 4428031/4370070/4475214.title: Will o' the Wisp or locally Willie the Wisp
4428031/4370070/4475214.text: Will o' the Wisp or Locally (Willie the Wisp.)When Our Lord was leaving the Garden of Gethsemani he appealed to one of the soldiers to have pity on Him, but the soldier only gave Him a slap on the back and said " Be off, be going with you ! " When this soldier died his soul appeared before the Lord. The latter remembered him and said " Be off, be going with you" but he gave Him a candle to light him on his way round the world till the day of judgement. He is now called Willie the wisp.T. Harte told by Annie Bourke Palmerstown Killala. Aged 65.

4428368/4400622/4487725.title: Will O' the Wisp
4428368/4400622/4487725.text:
Often in the Glen a light is seen at night, and my uncle said it was Will O' the Wisp.Will O' the Wisp is a spirit who could neither get into heaven or hell He is doomed to wander till the end, carrying in his hand a big light to show him the way. Will O' the Wisp was a blacksmith who sold himself to the devil for three years in order to get rich. The devil game him three years, and three wishes, and at the end of that time he was to come back, and take Will with him down to his kingdom. The first request Will asked was that anyone who got a hold of his sledge could never leave it down again until he allowed him to do so. The second was that anybody who sat in his chair he kept in the forge, couldn't get up, until he ordered him to; and the third, and last, was that any money Will ever put into his purse couldn't be taken out again by anyone except himself. The devil then went away saying he'd come back on that day three years. "All right," says Will, "I'll go with you."
(continues on next page)

4498770/4385631/4510292.title: Will o' the Wisp
4498770/4385631/4510292.text: Willo the Wisp.This is how we play "Willo the Wisp".Any number of children can play this game.n a dark night, one person goes out to hid carrying a flash-lamp, and when he is ready he flashes his lamp to show the followers where he is.The followers run in that direction and immediately "Willo the Wisp" runs in another direction, and when the followers go to the spot, he has gone, then they call "Willo the Wisp" show your lights.This is repeated until "Willo the Wisp" is caught.  Then another child is sent out and the same method is followed.

Will ' the Wisp is in Farney a wandering fairy who only appears in certain places at certain times.  Tom McCable a local fiddler of Aghnafareon Co. Monaghan related once that he saw Will ' the Wisp at the spot in a meadow where he had buried a cow.  Will ' the Wisp in the minds of the people of Aghnafareon townland was in some way associated with the burial place of dead domestic animals, as the cow and the horse.

4493754/4416774/4530947.text: There lived a man once upon a time, whose name was Will O' the Wisp. He was a blacksmith, and shoed horses.One day St. Joseph came to have his donkey shod. Will O' the Wisp shod the donkey. Then he asked St. Joseph for the money. St. Joseph said he had none. But St. Joseph, gave him three wishes. He took the three wishes, but he didn't wish to get to heaven. When he died he didn't get to heaven, and is wandering through the hill to this present day with a light.

There was once a poor blacksmith living in the district of Clifden. He used to get a fair share of work but he used to buy drink for the money. One day he was working very hard and he saw a man coming up the lane.  He was dressed in a big top hat and he had a short silver stick for walking.The man came into the forge and he asked the blacksmith what was his name. The blacksmith said my name is Willie. The gentleman said will you come with me in seven years time. I will said the blacksmith if you give me £200 to-day. "Alright" said the blacksmith. The man took out £200 out of his pocket and he gave it to the blacksmith. In seven years time I will call for you on the seventh hour of the seventh day of the seventh month of the seventh year.

4649698/4648248/4658842.title: Will o' the Wisp
4649698/4648248/4658842.text:
Once upon a time there was a man called Will Cooper and one day he was working in his forge when there came in another man and asked him for the use of his forge for a while, the man told him he could have it. The other man went out and was back in about five minutes hauling two old women after him. He put them in the fire, and when he took them out he hammered them on the anvil, until he hammered them in to one good woman.Will had a wife and mother in law that could never agree, and he thought that he would do the same as the other man did. He put them in the fire and they burned to death, then Will was worse than ever, and the man came back and fixed them the same as ever for him. When he was leaving he told Will that he would grant him three wishes, and to ask what ever he liked. Will agreed. First he asked that anyone who would lift his hammer could not leave it down until he took it from him. Secondly, that anyone who sat on his chair could not leave until he let them. Willie the WispStory taken down from Biddy Gilchrist  Annaughmaconway, Cloone, age 72 years. Farmers wife,maiden name Biddy Casey. This Casey family were great story tellers.Once upon a time there lived a blacksmith named Willie, and he was very poor. One day the devil came to him and said he would give him 100 pounds if he would come with him at the end of six months. Willie wanted the money so badly that he took it and gave the devil his promise. One day shortly after a saint and a little boy we going along the road with an ass and they went into the forge to set a shoe on the ass. Willie was so poor that he had no iron to make the shoe so he made it out of his hammer. When the saint saw what Willie had done, he gave him three wishes and they were: Anything that would get into his armchair would not get out till Willie would like; Anyone that got a hold of his sledge could not let it go till Willie liked; and anything that got into his purse could not get out of it till Willie would like. At the end of the six months the devil came for Willie. Willie was busy when the devil came putting hoops on a tub and he told the devil to rest himself in the chair till he was ready. When Willie had the job finished he told the devil he was ready to go but the devil could not rise from the chair. He squealed and –but it was no good so he told Willie that if he could release him he would give him six months more and another hundred pounds Willie let him go then. At the end of the second six months the devil came again and willie said that he would go with him when he had finished sledging a piece of iron. He asked the devil to help him sledge and when they had finished Willie said he was ready to go. But the devil could not let go the sledge. He shouted and roared and shook his hands but it was no good he could not drop the sledge so he told Willie he would give him another six months and another hundred pounds if he would take the sledge from his hands. Willie took the sledge from him and the Devil went.  At the end of the third six months the devil came again and this time he would neither sit in the chair or sledge to iron for Willie so that in the long run Willie had to go with him. As they were passing a public house willie saw two men drinking and he said to the devil “set those two men drunk and you can take them with you too, for it is easy for the devil to take drunken men.” ‘That is a good idea’ said the devil “but I have no money.” “Musha” said willie “you a poor devil if that’s any trouble to you I hear you can change yourself into many shapes and surely you can change yourself into a florin" So the devil changed himself into a florin and Willie put him into his purse and went home. The devil cried and shouted and said he would give thousands of pound and a whole life time to Willie if he would let him go. But Willie was not satisfied with that. He took the purse to the forge and placed it on the anvil and began to sledge it for all he was worth. The devil began to roar and said hilt or hair of him would never be seen in the world again if Willie would let him go. So Willie let him go and he never troubled him after. Willie lived to be very old and when he died he went up to heaven to get in. But St Peter met him at the gate and said he could not come there as he sold himself to the devil when on earth and to go to him now. So Willie had to go down to hell but when the devil saw him coming he was in a terrible state and he had all the devils working for all they were worth shutting the gates, locking them and building up fires against them. When Willie arrived at the gates the devil shouted that he would not let him in, that he would play some trick on them and told him to go back and St Peter again refused him. Then Willie tried to force his way in and St Peter threw a lighted candle at willie. TH candle struck Willie and knocked him down on the earth through the sky. When Willie was falling he caught the lighted candle and ever since at night he is flying around with his lighted candle and in the day time he blows the dust+ straws and thraunins up in the air and is called Willie the Wisp.
(continues on next page)

Long ago there lived a blacksmith who used to work in his forge. A man came to him. It was the devil. He said to the man whose name was Will Cooper "Will, it is in my power that you may make two wishes which I will give you seven days to think over" and then he went away. When the seven days were up the man came back again and said to Will "Have you the two wishes made up and what are they". Will said "I have and the first is :- any man who takes my sledge in his hand can not leave it down until I take it from him. The second is any person who sits down on my chair can not get up until I take him up". The man said to him "why did you not wish for heaven" and he went away. Sean was a very poor tinker, who lived near Loughrea, and he was told that the tinker trade was great in America.  So one day he started off to walk to Cobh [?] with the budget on his back, and when he was passing the bridge of Portumna he said "The devil will be with me when I come back here or I will have money."  He worked his way across to U.S.A.  He hired with a farmer for a year, and at the end of twelve months, he was only worth one shilling.  He was very much disappointed, and hired for another year.  He had the same story at the end of the second and third years, namely, he had only a shilling saved. I had remained in Wexford town one evening, longer than usual, and set out for home about nine o'clock in the evening, the time being early winter. I had the company of a neighbour on the road, and then had, in order to avoid a long way to my house to cross through many fields. I had not gone very far, when I saw a bright light before me, moving slowly. From the moment I saw it I became nervous, because it seemed to be coming nearer to me, and I thought I could see a shadow of a person holding it. Then it moved away again but never passed out of my sight. I went on, knowing that I was going in the direction of home but it was strange that my own roof was not to be seen, and at last the thought struck me that I was being led astray by the light, as I should have reached home in half the time. The man said "all right" and they started on their journey. The devil said he was very dry and he had better have a drink

5044686/5031954/5145778.title: How Will O' the Wisp Originated
5044686/5031954/5145778.text:
"There was a man one time of the name of Will Cooper, and he was very poor but was always a very good living man. A good fairy was passing the way one day and gave Will three gifts: one was that whoever took up the sledge couldn't lave it down till Will would like to let him. Another was that anyone sat down in Willie armchair couldn't get up without Will telling him the third was that anything went into his purse couldn’t come out without Will giving lave. In spite of all the gifts Will got poorer and poorer and one morning he was standing in the forge door and he said Id do anything for money. On the minute a little small man popped around the corner. Good morrow Will" says he.  Good morrow your honour says Will. 'Will ' says he ' I think you are in a bad way." Begorra and sure I am 'says Will 'Well Will says he 'if you promise to come with me after seven years I’ll lay you well off for the seven years, Ill give you plenty of money for that time' 'Agreed 'says Will.

5044681/5031572/5147521.title: Will-O'-The-Wisp
5044681/5031572/5147521.text: An old woman belonging to this Townsland told a story of Will o' the Wisp.  She said that she saw him every night for a whole week and on Saturday night her husband died suddenly.  She sent a neighbour to inform his brother and that the lights drew him astray and that he did not reach his destination for over three days.  When the brother came the funeral was over and he told the widow that Will o' the Wisp never led his family right.

5215788/5210890/5220661.title: Willie the Wisp
5215788/5210890/5220661.text:
There was once a blacksmith called Willie. He was a very wise man. He got three wishes. The first wish he had was that any one who would sit on his chair could not leave it until he would tell them to leave it. The next wish was that any one who would take his sledge he would not be able to stop sledging until Willie would tell him, and the third wish was that any money that would go into his purse could not leave it until he would take it out. 5235414/5235041/5235396.title: A Story of Billie the Wisp
5235414/5235041/5235396.text:
Once upon a time there was a man, a black-smith, he was doing a good trade and began to be poor and a little man came and to him he wanted to warm (himseff) himself and to boil some water.  After caling he said I will give you three wishes. The man was a fairy and the black-smith said I have a sledge I wish that whoever catches it cannot let it go I have a purse I wish that anything I put into it cannot be taken out until I release it.  I have a chair and I wish that anyone who sits down in it cannot get out of it until I release them.  The little man said "Why did you not wish for heaven when you die."The blacksmith got poor and he sold himself to the devil. 5260470/5255832/5261099.title: Will o' the Wisp
5260470/5255832/5261099.text: My father told me that he saw Willie the Wisp in Mr. Clery's bog.  It was like a red ball of fire going very fast.  If you followed it, it would lead you astray.

5260470/5255922/5262682.title: Will o' the Wisp
5260470/5255922/5262682.text: Mr Murphy had to get milk in Mr Byrnes of Punchestown.  One night he went across the field for it.  Will o' the Wisp appeared to him and he was forced to follow it about the field till dawn. My Father was coming home from Naas one night and Will o' the Wisp appeared to him and brought him back to Naas.

5260470/5256047/5262932.title: Will o' the Wisp
5260470/5256047/5262932.text: My father said he saw a litle light like a candle or a small lamp on the Commons and it went around the big pond three or four times and then it went up in the air and then it went over to Mullacash hill and he said it was Willie the Wisp.

5260470/5256180/5263090.title: Will o' the Wisp
5260470/5256180/5263090.text:
My father told me that when he was about fourteen years of age, he was crossing the limekiln of Harristown and he saw a little red ball of fire rolling along in front of him. He ran after it, but he could not catch it as when he would run it would roll quicker, and quicker, and when he would stop, it would stop.He followed it, all through Clarke's bottoms, across Major Mc Gees land and on to the railway and then it disappeared.
